Floating Hat. This is a normal hat that always floats a handspan above your head. It tips itself courteously to ladies and gentlemen.
Animated Goblet. This fine silver goblet floats above the table and will go refill itself from a cask or spring when ordered. It comes when called.
Animated Cutlery. This fine silver—a knife, fork, and spoon set—will dance for you, create ringing noise (as before a toast), and even carve a roast or stir soup or tea for you.
Glittering Shadow Powder. This powder adds luminous green, blue, or purple sparkles to your shadow.
Glimmering Hair Comb. While this comb remains in your locks, your hair shines and reflects light almost as bright as sunlight on water.
Flawless Raiment. These clothes are always clean, dry, fashionable, and well-tailored.
Purifying Canteen. The water poured from this canteen is always free of shadow corruption.
Umbral Incense. This incense draws shadows together in a 5-foot radius and burns for up to 15 minutes. Even in blazing sunlight, the conditions more closely resemble dim light.
Dawn Alarm. When the moons rise (or the sun, in the mortal realm or Summer Lands), this pale-white stone glows bright yellow, and a songbird sings.
Gilded Shadow. Your shadow is not black and gray but gold and silver. Your Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks are all at disadvantage.
Sunlight Candle. This candle burns with the full light of the sun in a 10-foot radius for 2 hours.

Phantasmal Tapestry. A traditional tapestry, often showing a unicorn, hippogriff, dragon, hunting party, or similar scene—but animated and often staring at the viewer. Depending on the subject, rabbits twitch, birds wheel about, waves crash on the shore, and wind sways the woven trees.

Perfumed Bath Tent. This tent resembles a bedroll or small rucksack. When shaken, it becomes a 10-by-10-foot tent complete with a wooden tub of hot water, fragrant pine or rose scents, and towels. It is far too thin to provide much protection against wind, cold, or rain, but it makes a fine way to remove the mud of roads and fields.
Everblooming Vase. Flowers placed in this vase never fade or wither.
Spider Silk Rope. With a sticky end as effective as a grappling hook and a weight of mere ounces, this 50-foot rope assists climbers with foot loops and can fit into a small pocket.

Watchful Bat. This small bat statue takes on the coloration of its perch and can watch for a particular person, creature, or event. When that person or event is witnessed, it finds you and tell you about it.
Icy Wind Fan. With a cooling breeze, the icy wind fan provides comfort on summer days.

entries.caption: Greater Umbral Items of the Shadow Fey
rows: Moon Helmet. This helmet is made entirely of transparent metal, so your vision is not obstructed.
Ebony Scabbard. A scabbard of purest darkness, it helps you gather shadows about yourself. You may attempt to {@action hide} while in plain sight once per day.
Animated Banner. This banner shows a moving, ferocious form of your heraldic crest, such as a lion rampant or a dragon breathing fire.
Umbral Palanquin. This palanquin seats one person and is carried by invisible forces. You need never walk anywhere.

Ephemeral Tent. This tent appears fully set when called, complete with brazier of coals, a pair of comfortable beds, and a small table set with nourishing food. It provides limited protection against bitter cold, storm winds, and heavy rain. Poor conditions may shred it.

Shadow Reins. These black reins with silver bells are hardly visible, but they are highly effective in transmitting your wishes to a mount. All Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) checks when dealing with a mount fitted with shadow reins have advantage.
Mooncatcher's Delight. This small amulet always draws moonlight to you. You'll never stand in darkness.
Phantasmal Feast. A deep-red tablecloth woven of shadows, it creates enough nutritious food for two creatures when placed on a table.
Dog Shadow. Your shadow resembles a faithful dog, which is watchful and barks when creatures approach. You cannot be {@quickref surprised|PHB|3|0|surprised}.

Sunlight Lantern. This hooded lantern burns with the full light of the sun in a 30-foot radius with dim light for an additional 30 feet. It burns for 6 hours on enchanted oil and can be damped to a 5-foot radius as needed.
Umbral Hunting Hounds. Two shadowy hounds that come when called. You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to follow a trail using scent.
Shadow Fanfare. A set of silver trumpets announces your arrival every time you enter a room.
Spider Silk Boat. The size of a handkerchief, it becomes a small, two-person rowboat when shaken out. It must be rowed normally but can be returned to kerchief size once you reach shore.

Ghost Jar. This jar can hold one ghost or phantom, which answers questions or moans hauntingly from time to time. If a second question is asked on any given day, a successful DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is required, or the ghost departs.

Whispering Pebble. A small stone that whispers nonsense without pause. If left alone in a room, it always sounds as if a conversation is happening, but the gist of it is never clear. If addressed, the stone falls silent.

Illusory Tower. This gleaming, transparent stone tower contains a single set of spiral stairs up to a height of about 50 feet. At the top, a flat platform and battlements provide an excellent view in all directions. The tower provides no cover or protection but is useful for seeing into the distance.

Evergroomed Kit. This pouch is made of oiled leather and holds various grooming products: such as shampoo, hair oil, a comb, a shaving razor, pressed powder, and a hand mirror. On spending 1 minute grooming yourself with the items from this kit, you are clean and fresh, hair perfectly styled, makeup party ready.

Feline Ring. This silver band creates an adorable illusory kitten. The kitten appears from behind a chair, someone's leg, or other cover and frolics and tumbles about. If approached, it flees and disappears once it's behind {@book total cover|PHB|9|Cover}.

Spectral Kestrel. This translucent bird of prey perches on your shoulder or wrist, keen-eyed and waiting. It can follow simple commands (such as fly, return, fetch, and harry) and has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks.

entries.name: Trickery and Whimsy
entries: The items in this section are tricks, art, and illusions done for show or to discomfit a rival without injury. These are performed with cantrip-level magic for the most part, though some merely use oils, scents, or ventriloquism. The fey gifts and glamours are charms or knacks sometimes bestowed as boons by fey lords and ladies to their followers or favorites. These gifts can be rescinded from those who fall out of favor.

entries.caption: Tricks and Pranks of the Gnomes and Shadow Goblins
rows: Frosty Frown. Your facial expression is frozen in a scowl for at least 1 hour. A DC 11 Constitution saving throw negates this.
Hidden Door. An important chamber's doorway is hidden behind an illusion. Courtiers seem to pass through the wall when they enter or leave this way.
Living Statue. A statue speaks and moves, mocking visitors or commenting on their choice of apparel.

Irritated Guard. Words are put in a guard's mouth, such as "You're not allowed here" or "Her majesty wishes you to leave the court at once." These are lies, but the guard is either {@condition paralyzed} or silenced and cannot correct the statement verbally.
Sewer Stench of Garlic. A particular set of boots or a cloak is infused with a rancid smell. Magic or several washings are required to get it out.
Rotting Garments. Your clothes are made to look moth-eaten, worn, patched, or otherwise slipshod.

Sliding Carpet. A carpet is infused with grease or oil that is not visible. Stepping on it requires a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, or you fall {@condition prone} (no damage except to dignity). When placed on a staircase, {@dice 1d6} falling damage may apply.
Enormous Belch. A huge belch seems to come from a genteel fey or human.
Stampede! A herd of sheep, goats, oxen, or cattle seems to be rushing down the hallway. Those who stand in its way are not injured, but goblins laugh at anyone who is startled.

Tiny Thieves. Trained crows, ravens, or even squirrels take food or small objects (such as buttons, laces, or hair pins) away from a creature and scamper off to the nearest tree or tower with their haul.
Storm Cloud. A small rain cloud follows you, drizzling on you (and only you) and leaving you damp.

entries.caption: Gifts and Glamours of the Fey
rows: Scent of Lemons and Roses. You smell of roses and lemons, even in the dead of winter or other unlikely times.
Flower Clothing. Your clothes are embroidered with flowers that sway in an unfelt breeze and that blossom, close, and turn to seed in a swift-flowing cycle of a few minutes.
Cloud of Kind Lights. You are surrounded by a cloud of wispy lights that always display you to advantage.
Deep Eyes like Pools. Your eyes are entrancing. If you succeed with a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, you can always catch another creature's eyes within 30 feet.
Entrancing Voice. Your voice is sweet or resonant; if you succeed with a Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check, you can always gather the attention of creatures within 30 feet.
Artist's Eye. You can describe any creature in detail or sketch it with uncanny accuracy.
A Fey Kiss. If a creature permits you to kiss it, your lips leave a lasting memory. Creatures you have kissed always remember you fondly, even if they never see you again.
Beguiling Caper. You dance with grace and beauty. At any party or festival where you dance, others stop to watch you.
Elegant Speech. Your rhetoric is sublime. You make Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks with advantage when first meeting a creature you share a language with.
Swift Rider. You can spur any mount to extraordinary speed. Your mount's {@action Dash} actions always add both your own speed and the mount's speed.

Follow Me. When you crook a finger at another creature, it often feels inspired to follow you. This applies as much to hounds and horses as it does to humanoids, fey, and giants. Sometimes, however, the charm fails; if {@spell Counterspell||counterspelled} by an arcanist or resisted by a powerful fey, you may be compelled to move toward the creature that you sought to draw close to yourself.

entries.caption: Beloved Illusions of the Fey Courts
rows: Enchanted Forest. A great hall or audience chamber resembles a lush forest of fragrant trees, ferns, and similar growth. Trees may hide doorways or balconies. It is difficult to tell what is a pillar and what is a tree.
Moonlit Hallway. An indoor hallway is lit by clear beams of moonlight.
Starry Carpet. The carpet resembles an open void filled with stars, comets, and moonlight. The carpet is disquieting to walk on.
Distant Towers. A set of tall, shining towers is visible from a balcony or window, but it is impossible to visit them. They are illusions near the horizon.

Silent Parade. A favorite of gnomes and fey children, a silent parade involves elves, goblins, bearfolk and erina, all marching and singing, shouting, playing trumpets, or pounding drums—but completely silent. Humans tend to find it eerie rather than hilarious.

Living Tapestry. Though similar to a phantasmal tapestry (see {@book Lesser Umbral Items of the Shadow Fey|BookOfEbonTides|11|Lesser Umbral Items of the Shadow Fey} above), these feature unicorns, hippogriffs, lions, or other animals that can exit the tapestry, wandering within 120 feet of it, fully alive.
Speaking Doors. A door with a metal knocker speaks and argues with those seeking to pass through it.
Infinite Hallway. The hallway seems to lead to a golden doorway, but walking down it never brings you any closer to the end.
Bed Monsters. Growling and hissing can be heard beneath a particular bed. When investigated, the space is empty.
Beehives. A section of window seems to be a transparent beehive with the bees themselves always visible.
Phantom Orchestra. Light chamber music drifts on the air without any obvious source, as if played by some small group always just out of sight.

entries.name: Life in Shadows
entries: The peoples of the Shadow Realm have adapted and thrived in a wide assortment of ways, stamping their own personalities and dreams into the realm.

entries.caption: Fashions of the Courts
rows: Shadow Silk Cloak. Woven out of darkness itself, a shadow silk cloak is a simple yet impressive accessory. This silky garment floats about you as if in a breeze and evaporates when removed, leaving behind nothing but the clasp until it is donned again.
Gossamer Veil. This veil is made from strands of gossamer and starlight, light as air and delicate as a dream.

Redcap. Found often in the shadow goblin courts, a redcap is a hat of any style dyed a deep, blood red. Those who hold to tradition dye their cap by soaking it in the fresh blood of a slain foe on a regular basis, but that custom has largely fallen out of favor—though the darakhul have taken up the tradition.
Heavens' Weave Clothing. Clothes made from heavens' weave fabric are black or dark blue and shimmer with constellations and star patterns of the mortal world.

Glass Gatorskin Accessories. Once tanned and dyed, the translucent skin of the glass gator becomes partially opaque, lending it a fascinating, crystal-like appearance, and it has the added benefit of being completely waterproof. Boots and gloves made of this material are especially popular with the shadow fey of all social classes, though only the nobility can readily afford them.

Sun-Stitched Raiment. Created and prized by the bearfolk of the Shadow Realm, these clothes are stitched over with luminous golden thread. The cloth is warm to the touch, as if laid out in the sun, and has a bolstering effect on your emotional state.
Moon Sable Fur Mantelet. Commonly considered a more feminine accessory, this short cape is made of the pure-white fur of the moon sable and is worn more for style rather than utility.

Living Tattoo. While not technically alive, these intricate tattoos are infused with illusion magic, allowing them to move and shift over your skin, and they can even travel from one part of the body to another based on your whims.

Sackcloth Clothing. Resembling prison garb, sackcloth clothing is a sign that you have been exiled from a court or city. Often a punishment in lieu of death, offending parties are stripped of belongings, dressed in sackcloth, and run out of town. Some wear the uncomfortable apparel as a form of atonement for their transgressions.
Moonglow Jewelry. The glowing gems in these elaborate accessories are made of moonlight, captured and cut into dazzling jewels.
Starlight Coronet. Tiny, shimmering motes of light encircle your head or sit nestled within your hair.

entries.caption: Beloved Pets of the Shadows
rows: Shimmer Serpent. This snake is 3–5 feet long but remains slender and delicate. The serpent is a solid, glossy black except for its belly, which features a shimmering, spangled pattern that resembles a starry night sky.
Moon Sable. A sleek, keen-eyed musteline with pure-white fur and the ability to convey simple emotions via empathic projection.

Umbraling. This piece of living shadow can be as small as a mouse or as large as a cat, and it takes on the form of whatever animal is most pleasing to its owner, though it has no features beyond a black silhouette.

Weal Bug. This jewel-green, cricket-like insect is often carried in a tiny, elaborate cage tied to the owner's belt or scabbard or even carried by a servant. It is said that its chirp draws good fortune to its owner and that it goes silent to warn of ill luck nearby.

Wolpertinger. A tiny creature, the wolpertinger (see {@i Creature Codex}) resembles a fanged rabbit with wings and horns. There are many breeds, from raven-black wolpertingers with a single spiral horn to the more common mottled-brown, deer-antlered variety.

Midnight Dragonette. Also known as the twilight dragonling, this tiny, dragon-like creature has an uncanny intelligence and a fondness for shiny trinkets. Its coloration tends toward blacks, greys, purples, and deep blues with the occasional hint of the deep reds of sunset. Its pupils are shaped like starbursts, and it breathes wreaths of purple vapor when happy.
Umbral Hunting Hound Puppies. A pair of shadowy puppies that come when called. They wrestle with each other, chase shadows, and are otherwise cute and cuddly.
Pocket Pig. This diminutive blue piglet is small enough to fit in a pouch or backpack. It is prized by some households for its ability to sniff out rare culinary ingredients.
Flutterby. This feline creature resembles a common housecat with large butterfly wings. Though only able to fly for short distances, it is a prized pet in many noble fey households.

Aetherfish. This shimmering fish "swims" in the air around its owner, its long, fan-like fins rippling gently in an unseen current. It occasionally takes on a ghostly appearance or momentarily disappears altogether as it passes too close to the border of the ethereal plane.

Lamplark. This diminutive songbird has soft gray-brown feathers and two distinctive black crescents just beneath its eyes. Belying its somewhat lackluster appearance, the lamplark sings beautiful and elaborate songs but only at night. When it sings, the lamplark glows like a golden beacon, shedding bright light in a 15-foot radius.

Snapdragon. A curious, sentient plant, the snapdragon has a long stem, broad leaves, and a vivid blossom that comes in a variety of colors. It is content to remain potted and indoors, though it can turn grumpy and brown if it outgrows its pot or if the pot is too plain for its tastes. An unhappy snapdragon has the tendency to bite.

entries.caption: Foods of the Shadow Realm
rows: Twilight Venison Stew. This hearty stew is made from the meat of the deer that wander the Shadow Realm, cooked in a rich, thick gravy with white and purple root vegetables. It is enjoyed by all classes and creatures within the Realm.
Air and Darkness Chiffon Cake. This fluffy, airy cake is flavored with a dark, bitter chocolate and topped with powdered sugar and black walnuts.

Fried Scuttles. Scuttles are a white beetle found feasting on deadfall in shadowy forests. Once fried, they become tender yet their shells crispy, and they're often served with a side of stinging nettle sauce for dipping. This dish is favored by the shadow goblins, erina, and some alseid.
Sautéed Midnight Morels. Conical black mushrooms cooked in butter and topped with shadow salts. Raw, this fungus is toxic, but cooked properly, it takes on a nutty, earthy flavor.

Golden Nightjar. Dusk-singing whip-poor-will roasted in a crust of saffron. Each chef adds additional spices to create a custom version of the dish, and the requisite saffron turns the skin and meat of the cooked bird a deep yellow.

Dreamingwine. A sweet dessert wine, this deep-red digestif is made with grapes that have been exposed to noble rot and the daydreams of young lovers. A small family of wyrd gnomes have begun developing a new vintage, made with white grapes and the bitter regrets of one dying of old age.
Candied Twilight Pears. This purple fruit is sliced thin and simmered in honey. It's served warm with a side of clotted cream. Consuming it conveys a temporary sense of mild euphoria.

Stygian Swill. A cheap and heady spirit made by distilling wheat or other grain with waters from the Styx or Lethe. It is highly potent and extremely bitter, and those not native to the Shadow Realm often find they wake the next day with memories that do not belong to them.

Whisper Blossom Pods. The long, finger-shaped seed pods of the whisper blossom are a versatile and delicious side dish. They can be battered and fried, sautéed in butter, or even added to stews and soups to add a dash of spice and melancholy.

Glass Gator Sweetbreads. The breaded and fried glands and organs of the glass gator are a particular delicacy in many noble households. The transparent nature of the creature and its meat make it difficult to hunt and butcher, making this a costly offering.

Steamed Shadowspider Legs. While the legs of the shadowspider matron are black and spiney, the meat within is light and flakey when steamed. This dish is often served with clarified butter seasoned with black truffle.

entries.caption: Cantrips of the Fey
rows: Eldritch Blast. Your {@spell eldritch blast} briefly leaves behind a lingering trail of illusory flower petals, falling leaves, or butterflies in the color of your choice.
Light. Though your {@spell light} spell provides the same illumination as always, it appears as a purple-black glow casting off dark rainbows.
Spare the Dying. When you cast {@spell spare the dying}, shadows pour from your mouth and fingers and sink into your target's chest.
Resistance. When you cast {@spell resistance}, your target is surrounded by iridescent, sparkling motes that remain until the spell ends.
Mage Hand. Your {@spell mage hand} appears as a knobby, twisted hag's hand.
Message. When you cast {@spell message}, your voice arrives at the target's ear, discordant and disconcerting, with whispered echoes and strange voices layered among your own.
Produce Flame. When you cast {@spell produce flame}, the fire appears as black, blue, pink, or purple.
Mending. When you cast {@spell mending}, dozens of tiny, shimmering spectral beetles envelop the damaged area, dissipating into glittering smoke when the spell is complete.
Dancing Lights. Your {@spell dancing lights} appear as swarms of blue and purple fireflies, spectral glowing goblin skulls, or tiny illusory moons.
Shillelagh. When you cast {@spell shillelagh}, the wood of your staff or club becomes twisted and black and glowing, wicked-looking thorns emerge from it.
Guidance. When you cast {@spell guidance}, your target's eyes are briefly framed by glowing purple or smoky black butterfly wings.

entries.caption: Omens of the Shadows
rows: Raven Feather. A single black raven feather in your path means death will find you soon.

Dancing Stars. Occasionally, a star may reorient itself in the heavens, moving from one point in the sky to another. This indicates shifting allegiances—either one that is already in place or one that should be strongly considered.
Backward-Flowing River. If you stumble upon a portion of the Styx or Lethe that is flowing in the wrong direction, the spirits are unquiet or displeased with your current course of action.
Rotten Fruit. If you bite into a piece of fruit and find it rotten, someone close to you will soon betray you.

Colored Flame. If your candle or fire burns blue, the time is ripe for you to act. If it burns black, beware a blade in the dark. If it burns purple, you'll have a visitor soon. If it burns green, good news is on its way.
Cracked Cauldron. A crack appearing in your cauldron or other dishware means you'll soon meet your love.
Stryx Shadow. A stryx shadow crossing over you means your current path leads to tragedy.
Phantom Knock. If you hear a knocking but find no one there, a known secret must be kept at all costs.
Thick Mist. A heavy mist or fog means the spirits are trying to convey a message. It is the ideal time to attempt to contact the dead.
Spilled Wine. If someone spills their wine at dinner, they will die within two nights. If you spill someone else's wine, their death will be your fault.
Spare Tooth. If you discover an unexpected tooth—in your food, on the ground, or even in your own mouth—good luck is with you.

entries.caption: Mounts in the Shadows
rows: Lesser Unicorn. Also known as a false unicorn, this creature resembles a slender white horse with split hooves and a single shimmering horn on its forehead. It lacks the intelligence and magical abilities of a true unicorn but can use an action to teleport up to 60 feet when in moonlight. Its speed is 50 feet.
Valravn. This mount has the body of a wolf with the head and wings of a raven. It has a speed (including flying) of 50 feet.

Horned Frog. This black and purple amphibian has two unicorn-like horns that protrude just above its eyes. With a speed (including swimming) of 40 feet, a long jump of 30 feet, and a high jump of 20 feet, this mount is especially advantageous in areas of uneven terrain.

Racing Snail. This large snail's spiraling conical shell comes in a variety of hues, and the top breeders pride themselves on creating new and unique color combinations. The racing snail has a speed (including climbing) of 50 feet and can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Giant White Rook. This white bird has dark eyes and a keen intelligence. It has a speed of 10 feet and a fly speed of 60 feet. It can follow simple instructions and can mimic short phrases of six words or less.

Sylvan Hare. Also known as a sylvie, this Medium rabbit has feather-soft fur—in black, dark gray, or white—red eyes, and overlong ears. It has a speed of 40 feet, a long jump of 30 feet, and a high jump of 20 feet, and it has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks related to sound. Halflings in the Shadow Realm prefer sylvies as their mounts.
Aquileona. A white and gold lion with a thick mane and broad, eagle-like wings, the aquileona is a fierce and terrifying mount. It has a speed (including flying) of 50 feet.

Marbled Widow. A mottled black and white spider, the marbled widow has slender legs, a bulbous abdomen, and paralyzing venom (DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute). Though its speed is only 40 feet, it can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check, and it has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) rolls.

Onyx Moa. This Medium flightless bird has jet-black feathers, wicked talons, and a broad, razor-sharp beak. With a speed of 60 feet, it's able to outpace many creatures and is the favored mount of the Shadow Realm's goblins and gnomes.

Reitenhund. A sleek black and brown canine, the reitenhund is the ideal mount for hunters and trackers. It moves quickly, with a speed of 60 feet, and has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks when tracking prey.

Kalong. A fuzzy black bat with a foxlike face, the kalong is awkward and slow on the ground but particularly quick and agile in the air. It has a speed of 10 feet and a fly speed of 60 feet, and it has {@sense blindsight} to 60 feet.

entries.caption: Strange Servants of the Shadows
rows: Knitter. Appearing as a humanoid or fey woman with overlarge solid-black eyes, a knitter has two extra sets of arms that she normally keeps hidden beneath her clothes. Knitters are highly proficient in dexterous tasks, including sewing, mending, weaving, and crochet, but her extra arms come in handy for all sorts of jobs.

Shadow Attendant. This shadowy, humanoid form coalesces out of the darkness when called and returns to the shadows when dismissed. It can perform simple tasks, like tending to a fire, cleaning, serving drinks, and carrying written messages.

Chatterbox. A 2-foot-tall, white-skinned humanoid with a too-wide mouth and vacant eyes, the chatterbox makes a magical record of any conversation it hears and can repeat it back verbatim later. They often replace scribes for nobles who need to constantly jot down lists or reminders—and the opportunities for spies are endless.
Pyreflies. These Tiny insects flit from room to room, kindling fires in hearths and lighting candles as darkness falls.

Nanny Goat. This goatlike humanoid has horizontal, rectangular pupils, two small, curved horns, and is quick and agile on their hooved feet. They're often employed as an assistant to nursemaids and governesses to shadow fey children.

House Brownie. Tiny and shy, the house brownie is very rarely seen, but the fruits of its labor manifest as mysteriously completed household tasks. A fireplace cleaned, floors scrubbed, and pots and pans sparkling in the drying rack are all evidence of a house brownie. While it only requires payment of milk and honey, those who go out of their way to befriend a house brownie find their kindness repaid in unexpected ways.

Skullery Maid. This Small skeleton walks on two legs but does not resemble any of the known humanoids in the Shadow Realm. Its head is a horse's skull, and its eyes burn with white fire. It cleans, mends, and does simple chores in exchange for the ashes from the hearth, which it consumes with gusto.

Teacup Fairy. So named because they're small enough to sleep in a teacup, this Tiny, winged fey cultivates tea and other herbs in the kitchen garden. They bite anyone who interferes with their work, gets in their way, or otherwise annoys them.

Shadow Watchman. This guard blends neatly with the darkness, standing at its post atop ramparts, parapets, or even outside a chamber door, alert for any encroaching danger. It requires no sleep or food, making it the ideal guard.

Umbral Butler. Punctual, tidy, and unfailingly polite, the umbral butler is the ideal head servant. If the other servants resent working beneath a creature made entirely of smoke and shadow, they never show it.

Silent Squire. A humanoid with white skin, hair, and eyes, the silent squire is perfectly attentive to a knight's every need, ready with shield, sword, or lance. Just don't look too deeply into their eyes—lest they look back.

entries.caption: Secrets of the Courts
rows: Lightweight. They cannot hold their liquor, and they spill others' secrets when drunk.
Dalliance. They are carrying on a secret affair with someone scandalous.
Blackmailer. They know someone else's secret and are blackmailing them to keep it quiet.
Indebted. They are not nearly as wealthy as they appear to be. They are heavily in debt to unscrupulous moneylenders or are pawning off old family heirlooms in order to afford the newer fashions.
Parricide. They killed a family member, either through an arranged killing or by their own hand.
Imposter. They are not who they say they are.
Conspirator. They are part of a plot to unseat the ruling monarch of their court.
Allergy. They are deathly allergic to a common food.
Sticky Fingers. They steal things. A lot. It could be small trinkets, large amounts of coin, or even priceless heirlooms.
Star-Crossed. They are in love with someone they can never be with.
Illusory Appearance. They heavily modify their appearance with illusions and enchantments, far past what is considered socially acceptable.

entries.caption: Tresures and Trinkets of the Shadows
rows: Memento Mori Music Box. This palm-sized music box is made of etched silver. When wound, it plays an eerie and entrancing melody. The inside of the lid holds a lock of black hair set behind glass.
Gemstone-Studded Fan. This fan is made from teal ostrich feathers, held together at the base by gilded ribs adorned with onyx cabochons.

Bloodletting Brooch. This tiny and extremely sharp dagger is disguised as a fashionable accessory, hidden within the design of a silver and garnet brooch. It can easily be carried into an event where weapons are frowned upon.

Pressed Memories. A 3-inch-square frame holds five different colored blossoms pressed between glass. Each blossom is an important memory, removed from the owner's mind and preserved—and promptly forgotten.
Everlight. This handheld taper burns with a warm golden glow and never gets any shorter.

Book of Secrets. A small journal bound in strange black leather, its pages are filled with fine writing in elegant calligraphy—and it's completely encoded. It holds the secrets of dozens of luminaries and other important beings but requires the cypher to translate, and it resists magical means to bypass the code.

Gilded Hummingbird Nest. This tiny accessory is created by harvesting a real hummingbird nest and coating it in gold, silver, or bronze—eggs and all. It is then worn in the hair or hung by a chain around the neck.
Kintsugi Teapot. An elegant black stoneware teapot that has been shattered and repaired with gold.
Porcelain Unicorn. This tiny, delicate statuette bears an uncanny resemblance to the real thing, having perfectly rendered features.
Shadowsphere Pendent. This marble-sized glass sphere holds a tiny, shifting wisp of shadow or black smoke. The wisp is constantly moving and changing.
Luminous Shard. This crystalline shard is 1 foot long and sharp as a knife. It glows softly whenever music is played in its vicinity.

entries.caption: Lore of the Bearfolk Druids
rows: The Cracked Oak Circle. This bearfolk grove is built around a massive, broken oak tree in the center of their settlement. Green and alive when the bearfolk settled here, the oak was split by dark lightning some decades ago from a darakhul sorcerer locked in battle with the grove's elder. The sorcerer ultimately escaped, the elder died, and the tree never recovered. The bearfolk who train here are educated on the ways of the darakhul and their undead, all the better to destroy them.

The Banshee-Haunted Grove. This tiny grove rests on the edge of an ancient battlefield. The site was initially chosen in order to watch for any undead, and when a banshee arose, she was immediately destroyed by the druids. However, she rose again the next night and was put down again—only to rise once more the night after that, and the night after that. After more than a week of this cycle, the bearfolk realized she had no intention of harming anyone within the grove if left alone, and they have instead taken to studying her pathways through the forests and fields in the hopes of discovering her origins and putting her to rest.

The Circle of Song. The natural stone henge of the Circle of Song is a curiosity. Carved by the wind whistling through the hillsides, on a gusty day, the stones of the grove sing as air passes through dozens of holes and passageways. Its strange geography also seems to be a focus for magic, and the druids of the Circle of Song can channel their abilities and shape the natural flow of the Shadow Realm around them with ease. They have learned to harmonize their own singing with the songs of the stones, creating a unique form of ritual.

The Moonshadow Grove. The druids here are attuned to the shadows and can pass between the pools of darkness with ease. Recently, however, something has infested their grove's shadows, and those who attempt to step between them do not always reappear.

The Moonfire Circle. In the center of this druid grove stands a brazier filled with cold-burning fire. The flame gives off a hollow white light and no warmth. It is harmless to living creatures from the mortal world but burns undead and those native to the Shadow Realm. Unfortunately, due to its nature, the druids have been unable to get the flame to grow or spread—it does not ignite wood, paper, or other flammables like true fire does. If they can learn how to manipulate it, it would be a powerful weapon indeed. So far, they have managed to keep its existence a secret from other Shadow Realm denizens, for surely such a tool would never be allowed to remain in bearfolk hands if the shadow fey had any say over it. But it is only a matter of time until word gets out and armies descend upon them.

The Grove of the Three Rivers. This grove is built in and around a fork of three small tributaries that branch off from the Styx and empty into three small pools. The bearfolk tend to these shadowy waters, attempting to commune with the souls trapped within. They have met with moderate success and have thus far "rescued" roughly 20 souls, encouraging them to pass on in some cases and sending them off as Stygian shades to discover the manner of their death and the secrets of their life in others. The druids here call themselves shade whisperers and find that violence is not the only answer to the evils of the Shadow Realm.

The Bent Tree Grove. The druids of this grove have created an intricate, living housing system created by coaxing the trees to grow in certain designs and directions. Though they are patient when it comes to home construction, the druids are merciless in their training of shadow gnawers and have no hesitation when it comes to cutting out the rot of shadow corruption wherever they find it.

The Circle of the Seven Sisters. Established by seven sisters who arrived in the Shadow Realm from the Arbonesse Forest, the Circle of the Seven Sisters has a tenuous connection to the mortal world. A pool of clear, fresh water stands in the center of the grove. The pool is fiercely guarded, both as a source of untainted water and as a pathway between the realms. Creatures who submerge themselves completely in the pool and swim directly toward the bottom for 1 minute emerge in the mortal world in Riverbend within the Arbonesse. Following the pathway back into the Shadow Realm is trickier however since the way through the river is only open during certain phases of the moon.

The Hearthollow Grove. Once a grove with many students and teachers, the Hearthollow Grove is now all but abandoned. Only the caretaker, Umalla, remains, and no bearfolk travel here anymore. Recently, even communication with Umalla has gone silent, and none of the bearfolk know the reason for the loss of this stronghold.

The Blackwater Grove. Nestled on the banks of a massive lake, the druids of the Blackwater Grove have pulled something curious coffin from the shadowy waters. The box is made of heavy iron and etched with runes, and though it seems old, it shows no signs of rust or other degradation. Still, something is within, and the bearfolk here argue about whether they should open it, guard it, or return it to the lake. So far, Ellar Dannos, the bearfolk leader of this grove, has been content to study it in quiet contemplation for endless hours.

The Circle of the Gloomflower. Once a massive grove of gloomflowers, a large swath of forest was cleansed by bearfolk druids who established the Circle of the Gloomflower. Though a latent psychic scream still pierces the air periodically, an echo of a memory of darker times in the land, this grove has known relative peace for some time now. Not long ago, however, the patrolling druids discovered some strange silver seeds that buffeted them with corrupting visions when touched. The gloomflower grove may be returning—either through natural means or by someone's hand.

data.name: Appendix: Shadow Realm Encounters
entries: You never can quite know what you'll run across in the Shadow Realms. Walk softly.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Forests (CR 1-4)
rows: The ruins of a crumbling stone palace stand before you. Partially collapsed walls hide whatever treasures may lie within. PCs who indulge their curiosity and enter the ruins are attacked by two {@creature Cobbleswarm|ToB1-2023|cobbleswarms} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|3}), masquerading as the stone floor.

A gruesome scene of violence lies in the clearing just ahead. Several corpses picked entirely clean lay on the ground, but one in the clearing center is covered in dozens of black butterflies. The butterflies are a {@creature death butterfly swarm|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) that attacks if the corpses are disturbed.

Painful groans alert the PCs to a {@creature sable elf|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Sable Elf}) bound to a tree. The {@b lunarchidna} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) that wrapped the elf waits above in the tree to ambush any rescuers.

A small fire alerts you to a camp occupied by eight {@creature Shadow Fey Forest Hunter|ToB1-2023|shadow fey forest hunters} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}). The fey are happy to share their fire with polite travelers and warn them that an unusual amount of lycanthropes have been seen in this region of the forest.

A {@creature giant elk} bearing a {@creature far darrig|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|6}) bounds onto the path. The far darrig is under orders to guard this path and demands the PCs turn back. If the PCs do not comply, both the elk and its rider attack.

The PC with the highest passive Perception hears a tiny voice call out from the ground. The voice belongs to an enchanted snail who would like to be placed on a tall branch just above. A character who helps the snail gains the benefits of the {@spell bless} spell for 24 hours. A character who harms or kills the snail has the penalty of a {@spell bane} spell for 24 hours.
The PCs step into a grove covered in booby traps left by a tribe of {@creature Moss Lurker|ToB1-2023|moss lurkers} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}).

A bedraggled {@creature veteran} stumbles onto the path and begs the PCs to help end its torment. The veteran slew a bird while hunting for food and has become the target of a vengeful {@creature pombero|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|16}).

A clearing in the forest admits the shining silver light of the moons above. In the center of the clearing stands a solitary {@b gloomflower} (see {@i Creature Codex}), illuminated by a beam of moonlight.

A {@b shadow blight} (see {@i Creature Codex}) has found its way to this part of the forest, searching for dead trees to infect with its taint. It stands motionless next to one such tree, waiting for the PCs to pass.

A lumbering bear comes into view. It raises its head, and its deer-like antlers and burning red eyes mark it as more than a normal bear. The {@b spawn of Chernobog} (see {@i Creature Codex}) roars and attacks.

A {@b wolpertinger} (see {@i Creature Codex}) sits in the party's path. It hops once, then twice, off the path and into the underbrush. If the party follows, it leads them to their destination in half the time. If the party attacks, it flees.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Forests (CR 5-9)
rows: A trio of {@creature Deathwisp|ToB1-2023|deathwisps} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) begins to stalk the party. These wisps are born of three murdered shadow fey who mistakenly believe the PCs are the adventurers responsible for their death.

The party is approached by a {@creature bearfolk druid|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Bearfolk Druid}), tracking a creature corrupted by shadow. The druid offers the party information or a safe place to shelter for the night in exchange for assistance in hunting the beast.

A chorus of barks heralds the arrival of two {@creature Hound of the Night|ToB1-2023|hounds of the night} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|8}) followed by a {@creature keeper of hounds|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Keeper of Hounds}). The keeper is training the dogs to hunt humanoids, and they are delighted to sick the dogs on such vulnerable prey.

Haunting rustling carries on the wind as two {@creature Birch Siren|BookOfEbonTides|birch sirens} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Birch Siren}) have flanked the party, hoping to ensnare them with enchantment.

The corpse of an enormous bear lies in the clearing ahead, ensnared by a bear trap. The trap is a {@creature gnarljak|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}), hoping to prey on any creature inspecting the corpse.

A chorus of voices leads you to an overgrown black chapel. Inside, four {@creature Owl Harpy|ToB1-2023|owl harpies} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|8}) sing hymns praising {@b Alquam} (see {@i Tome of Beasts}), the demon lord of night.
The PCs are ambushed by a pair of {@creature malphas|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}), assassins ordered to kill the party at the behest of their mysterious shadow fey lord.

The path ahead is filled with black webbing. A successful DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check reveals these webs aren't from a spider, and if the DC is exceeded by 5 or more, it is identified as webbing from a {@b somberweave} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}).

The PCs hear sobbing cries for help. If they investigate, they discover a shadow fey trapped in the cage atop the head of a lumbering {@b chuhaister} (see {@i Creature Codex}). The giant entered the Shadow Realm to destroy the fey on their home turf and has been harrying nearby villages.

A pile of armor and other belongings can be seen through the trees. The items lie beneath a {@b goliath longlegs} (see {@i Creature Codex}) that attacks with its Paralytic Web when the PCs are within range.

An {@creature Alseid|ToB1-2023|alseid grovekeeper} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|1}) and three {@creature alseid|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|1}) circle the party and demand to know why they are in their woods.

Three {@creature myling|ToB1-2023} approach the party for help in finding their final rest. They lead the PCs to a dense copse of corpse-white trees, where they attempt to drag the PCs into the ground.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Forests (CR 10+)
rows: Profane chanting comes from the grove just beyond where five {@creature Druid||druids} conduct an evil ritual under the guidance of a {@creature lunar devil|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}). If the devil is destroyed, the corrupting enchantments on the druids are broken, and they are horrified by their actions.

A wounded {@creature Berstuc Demon|ToB1-2023|berstuc} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) stumbles onto the path with two {@creature Treant||treants} following closely behind. The berstuc pretends to be a treant, running from the shadow-corrupted treants, and begs the party to help fight off the pursuers. If the PCs fall for this trick and the berstuc survives, it immediately turns its attack on the party.

Baying hounds and rallying horn blasts ring through the night as the {@creature Lord of the Hunt|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|6}) passes through the wood. Every humanoid that can hear the horn must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be compelled to follow the lord through the night.

The party happens upon a {@creature mavka|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}), setting fire to a huge swath of forest. She gives the party one chance to walk away, no questions asked, but attacks if they interfere.

The earth groans as something massive moves far below your feet, sudden tremors rock the ground, and ancient trees fall into a widening chasm in the earth. The PCs must succeed on a DC 18 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to outrun the fissure, or they fall 100 feet into the dark.

The sounds of tinkling music and laughter draw you toward a garden party on the lawns of a glittering marble estate. The shadow fey and gnomish nobles in attendance are delighted to introduce inquiring PCs to the host, the {@b Mistress of Midnight Teeth} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}).
You catch glimpses of dark figures just beyond the tree line. PCs who take a closer look discover the figures are overgrown stone statues that look remarkably like the characters.
Tinkling music comes from above as a breeze stirs through the trees. You see hundreds of chimes made from humanoid teeth are hanging from the tall branches.

An {@b ancient mandriano} (see {@i Creature Codex}) and three {@b mandriano} (see {@i Creature Codex}) lurk near a forgotten burial ground. When the PCs pass nearby, they attack. When one of the PCs dies or the ancient mandriano drops to 25 hp, it uses its Call the Dead ability to raise the PC's corpse or one of the bodies in the burial ground.

A {@b bearfolk chieftain} (see {@i Creature Codex}) and four {@creature bearfolk|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|2}) charge into view, pursuing three {@creature Umbral Vampire|ToB1-2023|umbral vampires} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|22}). If the PCs aid the bearfolk in destroying the vampires, he thanks them with gifts of fresh food and water and an open invitation to his grove.

A {@creature ravenfolk doom croaker|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|18}) and two {@creature Ravenfolk Warrior|ToB1-2023|ravenfolk warriors} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|18}) make their way through the forest. They ask to accompany the PCs for a time and share a campfire before going their own way.
A swarm of {@b nyctli} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) stalks the party for as long as it can without being spotted, spying for their mistress. If spotted, the swarm attacks.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Marshes and Rivers (CR 1-4)
rows: A trio of {@creature Shadow Fey Bandit|BookOfEbonTides|shadow fey bandits} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Shadow Fey Bandit}) are camped beside a ramshackle dock on the edge of a river. They offer to ferry the PCs across the river for a hefty sum of coin. If the party refuses, the bandits attack, planning to loot their corpses before pushing them into the river.

A group of merchants ({@creature Commoner||commoners}) stands arguing in a cluster just in front of a stone bridge, crossing a black river. A {@creature river spirit|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|River Spirit}) has recently taken possession of the bridge and won't allow anyone to pass until a champion defeats it in single combat.

The sound of flapping wings fills the air as three {@creature stryx|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|19}) land on the rocky shore ahead. The stryx are collecting information for the {@creature Moonlit King|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|6} and {@book Chapter 6|BookOfEbonTides|6|Court of the Moonlit King}), and they ask the PCs a series of odd questions before flying away.

The PC with the highest passive Perception notices that two {@creature Swarm of Ravens||swarms of ravens} have been following the party for the last hour. If the party does nothing, the ravens continue to watch the party while they remain in the area. If the party harms or interferes with the ravens, a {@creature keeper of ravens|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Keeper of Ravens}) appears to dole out justice.

One of the PCs has unwittingly caught the eye of a jealous shadow fey noble who sends a {@creature Swarm of Sluaghs|ToB1-2023|sluagh swarm} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|19}) to dispose of them.

A ball of gentle blue light appears in the distance, parting the oppressive gloom. It patiently bobs in place as if waiting for you to follow. The light is a friendly {@creature witchlight|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|23}) that guides the party safely to their destination if followed.

The PCs unwittingly catch the notice of a {@b woe siphon} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) that begins to stalk them. The party begins to experience an increasing series of annoyances and misfortunes until the woe siphon grows strong enough to attack or the PCs catch on to the presence of the creature.

A {@creature green hag} disguised as a lost traveler approaches the party asking for help. If the situation turns hostile, four {@b nyctli} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) spring out of hiding to help their mistress.
Three {@b shadow skeletons} (see {@i Creature Codex}) lie motionless beside the black waters of a shadowy river, waiting to ambush travelers.

A hungry {@b lou caracohl} (see {@i Creature Codex}) has extended its six tongues in a 60-foot-radius around itself. As the PCs pass near, they must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition restrained} (as per the creature's Sticky Tongues ability). If all the PCs avoid the tongues, it attacks.
A {@creature glass gator|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}) waits at the edge of the water, nearly invisible in the gloom.

Three {@creature Miremal|ToB1-2023|miremals} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}) offer to lead the party safely through the swamp but instead lure them deeper into the muck and mire until the PCs are lost and confused, and then they attack.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Marshes and Rivers (CR 5-9)
rows: A dwarf stumbles out of a nearby bank of reeds and professes to have no memory of who they are or what they are doing here. This dwarf is one of many victims of a local {@creature memory thief|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Memory Thief}) who has been stalking victims and staging them to think they've fallen into memory-leeching waters of the realm.

After miles of fetid bogs and brackish water, you spot a clear blue pond full of fresh water. The pond is a {@creature wandering pond|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Wandering Pond}) disguised as the only drinkable water amidst the marsh.

A {@creature shadow fey enchantress|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}) suddenly appears before you in a puff of smoke. The enchantress was recently banished from court and is interested in recruiting the PCs to help restore her position.

Far in the distance, the party sees a flickering purple figure, depositing something on a marshy bank before it disappears. PCs who investigate the spot find a series of stones arranged to spell "Behind You." The {@creature shadow beast|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|19}) who left the message materializes to attack.

Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check are alerted to the sound of squelching boots. Characters who fail this check are {@quickref surprised|PHB|3|0|surprised} as a group of three {@creature Redcap|ToB1-2023|redcaps} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|18}) spring to attack from the reeds.
Through the dense mist, you see a hunched figure, rooting through the mud. If the PCs attract any attention to themselves, the {@b faceless wanderer} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) moves to attack.

Sticking out of the water, you spot a black {@b crystalline monolith} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) covered in bizarre symbols. Anyone who speaks Void Speech recognizes the symbols as part of a prophecy heralding the return of an elder god.

You stumble upon a series of flat rocks laid out with a sumptuous feast. PCs who examine the scene notice a bright-yellow flower sprouted beside the table. The flower is a {@b swamp lily} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), and the feast is its poisonous trap.
As the PCs travel near a river, the waters churn and erupt as a {@b shadow river lord} (see {@i Creature Codex}) returns from the mortal world with a freshly reaped soul.

A beautiful elven woman steps out of the shadows between trees. Her edges are hazy and indistinct, but her eyes are intense and beguiling. The {@b moon nymph} (see {@i Creature Codex}) smiles and attacks.

As the PCs travel through the marshland, flickering ghostlights and shimmering clouds can be seen, always in the distance. A {@b foxfire ooze} (see {@i Creature Codex}) creeps closer to the party, using its natural camouflage to approach unseen.

Partially submerged ruins jut from the mud and water. An {@creature elder shadow drake|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) does not take kindly to the party intruding into its territory, and it attacks.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Plains, Hills, and Mountains (CR 1-4)
rows: From its hiding place, a {@creature domovoi|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) calls to the party, demanding that they pay a fine for trespassing on private property. The estate that once stood here is long gone, but the domovoi will not be pacified unless it receives something of value as payment.
An irate {@creature molefolk|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Molefolk}) pops out of the ground, demanding to know why the PCs are making such a racket right above their home.
The PCs run into two {@creature darakhul|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}), hunting for fresh meat.
A {@creature shadhavar|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|19}) has just escaped its cruel shadow fey master and tentatively approaches the party, hoping they can help it get to safety.

You come upon a circle of tall stones arranged in a circle. Something sparkles in the grass at the center. The sparkling object in a shiny rock laying atop a {@b carnivorous sod} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) disguised as grass.

Tucked amidst the rolling hills is a gated square surrounded by high stone walls. PCs who enter (the gate lock has long since rusted away) find the remains of a monastery garden kept by a lonely {@b dancing foliage} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}).
Glass marbles are hurled at you from twisted briars just beyond. An {@b orphan of the black} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) creeps through the brambles, hoping the party wants to play.

Two {@creature Shadow Fey Forest Hunter|ToB1-2023|shadow fey forest hunters} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}) come running down the hillside toward you, pursued by an oozing black {@b overshadow} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}).
A {@b dark father} (see {@i Creature Codex}) has begun trailing the party. It is not hostile until attacked, and it instead watches them from a distance, though always within view.
Six {@creature bucca|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|2}) emerge from a nearby cave to attack the passing PCs.

A silent, cloaked figure approaches the party through the gloom. It does not answer any shouted inquiries, nor does it remove its hood. The figure is a {@creature mindrot thrall|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}) that continues toward the group until it is close enough to engulf most of the party with its Acid Breath.
A massive, horned beetle rushes toward the party. The beetle is actually a {@creature skitterhaunt|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|19}), infesting the carcass of a giant beetle.

entries.caption: Encounters in the Plains, Hills, and Mountains (CR 5-9)
rows: A sudden explosion draws attention to a ramshackle building—and it is engulfed in flames. Two squabbling {@creature Gnomish Distiller|BookOfEbonTides|gnomish distillers} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Gnomish Distiller}) run outside their laboratory and attack each other if the party does not intervene.

A {@creature knight of shadows|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Knight of Shadows}) has grown bored while patrolling the region and approaches the party for some entertainment (torment).

You nearly trip over a human sleeping in the grass. A {@creature rose golem|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Rose Golem}) guards the ruins of a nearby estate and has put several recent passersby to sleep.

Raucous laughter and music drift down the hillside from a camp of 13 {@creature Satyr||satyrs}. The satyrs are happy to wine and dine the party but intend to slit their throats and rob any PCs who let down their guard.
The PCs run into two {@creature Iron Ghoul|ToB1-2023|iron ghouls} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}), hunting for fresh meat.

On the hill just beyond, you can see the smashed remains of a massive stone gate. PCs who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check know that this gate was once a giant portal to the mortal world. Only a creature of immense power could have completely destroyed such a structure.
Sharp hissing is the only warning given before the party is swarmed by two {@creature Umbral Vampire|ToB1-2023|umbral vampires} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|22}).

Sounds of clattering and pickaxes alert you to a mining operation just over the next ridge. PCs who investigate find a band of darakhul led by a {@b darakhul captain} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), forcing a band of enslaved {@creature Commoner||commoners} to dig out a collapsed cavern.

A {@b shadow fey knight of the road} (see {@i Creature Codex}), riding a {@b lou carcohl} (see {@i Creature Codex}), blocks the PCs' path and demands payment for passage through her territory. If the PCs refuse, she and her mount attack.
A {@b moon drake} (see {@i Creature Codex}) soars overhead. If the party follows it, they lose sight of it at an ancient circle of standing stones.
Six {@b flesh reavers} (see {@i Creature Codex}) have managed to get free of their handlers and are hunting the hillsides for living flesh. They converge on the party as soon as they are spotted.
A portion of the sod shifts and moves toward the party as a {@creature corrupting ooze|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|15}) slinks along the ground to attack.

entries.caption: Encounters on the Road (CR 1-4)
rows: A group of {@creature Commoner||commoners} led by a {@creature bearfolk thunderstomper|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Bearfolk Thunderstomper}) approaches from farther down the road. The bearfolk is escorting this group of settlers to the Moonlit Glades and offers to bring the PCs along.

A {@creature moonshadow catcher|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Moonshadow Catcher}) and their three {@b shadow goblin} minions (see {@i Creature Codex}) ambush the PCs, attempting to {@condition incapacitated|phb|incapacitate} them and take them to a local fey looking for test subjects.

Hooting and jeering comes from just ahead where a crowd of goblins watches two {@creature Shadow Goblin Chieftain|BookOfEbonTides|shadow goblin chieftains} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Shadow Goblin Chieftain}) fight. If the PCs watch the action, the losing chieftain offers the party a fortune to help him kill the winning chieftain. If the party accepts the offer, four {@b shadow goblins} (see {@i Creature Codex}) loyal to the winning chieftain join the fight.

A {@creature sable elf hierophant|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Sable Elf Hierophant}), escorted by two {@creature sable elf|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Sable Elf}) handmaidens, takes an interest in one of the characters. She extends an invitation for the PC to visit her at her patron's mansion.

A rowdy pair of {@creature Shadow Fey Duelist|ToB1-2023|shadow fey duelists} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}), escorted by a {@creature shadow fey guardian|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}), waylay any travelers they meet along the road.
The road before you is stained with slashes of black-crusted blood. The grisly trail leads to a flipped-over cart that has been torn apart. There are no signs of the cart's owners.

A solitary {@creature Ravenfolk Scout|ToB1-2023|ravenfolk} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|18}) dressed in black robes waves down the party. It politely asks for one of the PCs to sing a song. If the PCs oblige, the ravenfolk listens, whispers, "That's not the one," and hands the singer some gold for their time.
A recently exiled {@b scrofin} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) sits drinking on the side of the road. It waves over passersbys, eager to share its bottle and discuss its troubles with fey politics.

A piercing shriek fills the air and continues unabated until the PCs investigate or leave the area. If the PCs investigate, they find a young basket-carrying shadow fey {@condition unconscious} beside an uprooted {@b great mandrake} (see {@i Creature Codex}). The mandrake continues to use its Shriek ability and attacks any creature that come within 10 feet of it.
An inebriated {@b dhampir} (see {@i Creature Codex}) stumbles upon the party and begs their help in finding his signet ring, which he lost in a drunken scuffle with a shadow fey.

A dirty and scarred book lies abandoned on the side of the road. It might be a spellbook but will require more study to decode. An inkling (see {@i Creature Codex}) hides within, waiting until it is put in a bag with other books to explore its new surroundings and devour the ink on their pages.

A quiet, bookish shadow fey recently passed away, and his {@creature lantern dragonette|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) found itself on the streets. It approaches the party, asking for candles it can eat. If they're kind and feed it, it accompanies them for a time.

entries.caption: Encounters on the Road (CR 5-9)
rows: The imposing figure of a {@creature monolith champion|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|13}) greets you as it paces in front of a shrine just off the road.
A {@b fardorocha} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) approaches the party, bearing an invitation to a nearby fey estate.
A {@b fey revenant} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) has been given leave to hunt humanoids as a birthday present from the Queen of Night and Magic. The PCs are selected as the revenant's first quarry.

Just ahead, villagers crowd around a hastily constructed stage. The people look on in horror as a {@b jack of strings} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) uses their magic to force a young man to beat himself.

A carriage with blackened windows pulls up alongside the PCs. Its occupants are two {@b lunarians} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), hoping to get directions to the closest {@creature umbral tailor|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Umbral Tailor}). The lunarians hope the tailor can cure them of their curse, but they welcome any interested PCs to join them on their journey.

A gargantuan wall of thorns completely blocks the road. The PCs must leave the safety of the road to go around the thorns or confront the {@b thornheart guardian} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) that has created the blockage.

After a long stretch of travel through the cold fog, you see a stone guardhouse built along the roadside. It appears to be empty and to be a perfect place to rest. If the PCs take a rest in the guardhouse, they are attacked mid-sleep by one of the walls, which is a {@b walled horror} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}).

Thunderous hoofbeats come from behind as two {@creature Knight of Shadows|BookOfEbonTides|knights of shadow} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Knight of Shadows}) ride to destroy a trio of {@b werynax} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), causing havoc on the road up ahead. PCs who assist the knights in their hunt have the opportunity to garner favor with the courts.

A {@b karakura} (see {@i Creature Codex}) lurks in the shadows just off the road. As the PCs pass by, it uses its Shroud of Darkness ability on the last PC in the group. Since the PCs are already in the Shadow Realm, if the PC fails their Charisma saving throw, they are instead engulfed in an invulnerable cocoon of shadow until the effect ends.

A {@creature mirror hag|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|8}) has begun plaguing a nearby shadow fey town, delighting in causing chaos among the self-absorbed fey nobles. The hag disguises herself as an elderly fey and targets the PC with the highest Charisma score with her Reconfiguring Curse.

A miserable-looking dog approaches the party. The dog is a {@creature hulking whelp|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|8}) in search of friendship. If the PCs treat it kindly, it accompanies them as long as they allow it. If they harm or are otherwise cruel to it, it uses its Unleashed Emotion ability to grow in size and then attacks.

A {@creature kikimora|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|11}) has recently been forcibly evicted from the home it was plaguing. It spots the party and begs them to help it find new lodgings, where it will cause misery and destruction.

entries.caption: Encounters on the Road (CR 10+)
rows: The roads buckle beneath your feet as a flickering, gigantic figure phases into view. The figure is an irate {@b shadow giant} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), looking for any excuse to take out its frustration.
The mists part to reveal an abandoned village just off the road. The villagers fell prey to an {@b incarnate gloom} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}), eager to make the PCs its next meal.

A disguised {@b luck leech} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) approaches the PCs, challenging them to a "friendly" game of chance. If the luck leech begins to lose, it chooses to attack the victor and rob them.

A gleaming {@b repository} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) emerges from the mists, bearing an invitation for the PCs to dine with its {@b psychic vampire} (see {@i Tome of Beasts 2}) master. If the party accepts, the repository leads them to the vampire's nearby subterranean estate.

A team of {@creature Deep Gnome (Svirfneblin)||deep gnomes} has pulled off the side of the road to repair their broken {@creature steam golem|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}). The golem is a gift to the {@creature Queen of Night and Magic|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|6}), and the gnomes are desperate for help repairing it.

Screaming comes from just ahead as a squad of four {@creature darakhul|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}) are being chased by a hungry {@creature gug|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|7}).

Trails of smoke drift toward you from a burned-down village. Anyone who approaches sees a mountain of bodies blazing at its center. The village is actually an illusory haunt, and the bodies are a {@creature corpse mound|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|3}), which attacks anyone who comes close.

A being of shining golden light suddenly falls from the sky and lands before you. The {@creature Radiant Lord|BookOfEbonTides} (see {@book Chapter 9|BookOfEbonTides|9|Radiant Lord}) introduces themselves and politely asks if the PCs have seen any locations in their travels that would be fit for constructing an observation tower.

Hoofbeats can be heard as a {@b vampire patrician} (see {@i Creature Codex}), his three {@creature vampire spawn} escorts, and their mounts draw near to the PCs on the road. The vampire patrician will stop and exchange pleasantries with the party, for he's interested in their business in the Shadow Realm. The vampires are not hostile and only attack if attacked first.

An enraged {@b shadow fey ambassador} (see {@i Creature Codex}) and her {@b dream squire} (see {@i Creature Codex}) stand at the side of the road, robbed of their goods. The ambassador hails the PCs and demands they pursue the three {@b shadow fey knights of the road} (see {@i Creature Codex}) and retrieve their stolen belongings.
A {@creature dullahan|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|4}) gallops down the road, preparing to cut down the party and any who stand in their way.

A {@creature fear smith|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|6}), accompanied by a {@creature shadow fey guardian|ToB1-2023} (see {@book Tome of Beasts 1|ToB1-2023|5}), confronts the characters in a dark alley or lonely road.

entries.name: On the Road
entries: An extremely wide range of creatures from lowly stryx to Demon lords may be found on the Shadow Roads. Surprisingly, the more dangerous they are, the more often they seem to be in a hurry to get somewhere. Some encounters on a Shadow Road are nothing more than a passing nod to {@creature Demon Lord Camazotz|ToB1-2023|Camazotz}, Demon Lord of Bats, as he flutters past.

data.name: Tactical Maps for the Shadow Realm
entries: The maps below include a fey village, a shadow road, a stretch of the River Styx, and other areas with the twilight shades and native flora emblematic of the Shadow Realm. The maps can be used for any encounter on the plane to enhance its shadowy atmosphere and fey landscapes.
